stem: Match the following neurological findings to the most likely affected area of the brain.

rationale.correct: Left MCA: Right-sided hemiparesis and expressive aphasia are classic signs of a stroke affecting the left middle cerebral artery (MCA). These areas control motor function and language, respectively, on the contralateral side of the body. Cerebellum: Ataxia and balance problems are commonly associated with cerebellar dysfunction. The cerebellum coordinates movement and balance. Occipital Lobe: Visual disturbances, such as hemianopia or cortical blindness, are characteristic of occipital lobe damage. The occipital lobe processes visual information. Temporal Lobe: Auditory processing and memory consolidation are primarily functions of the temporal lobe; hence, difficulty understanding speech (receptive aphasia) indicates temporal lobe involvement.

mnemonic.name: FAST
mnemonic.description: Face drooping, Arm weakness, Speech difficulty, Time to call 911 – helps identify stroke symptoms quickly.

rationale.incorrect: Each of the incorrect pairings suggests a different location than where the neurological findings are actually originating. For example, patients experiencing right-sided weakness will not experience cerebellar dysfunction. Rather, that will be localized to the contralateral side of the brain, which is the left MCA. Confusing the affected side of the brain with the side of the body exhibiting symptoms (contralateral vs. ipsilateral) is a common error.

questionTrap.reason: A thorough understanding of neuroanatomy and the contralateral nature of motor and sensory pathways is necessary to answer correctly. Students must differentiate between expressive and receptive aphasia and their corresponding brain regions.
questionTrap.commonMistake: Students may confuse the affected side of the brain with the side of the body exhibiting symptoms (contralateral vs. ipsilateral).

clinicalPearls: Time is brain: Rapid assessment and intervention are crucial in acute stroke management. Every minute counts to minimize brain damage.
The NIHSS score is a valuable tool for quantifying neurological deficits and guiding treatment decisions. It helps standardize assessments and track patient progress.
CT head without contrast is essential to rule out hemorrhage before administering tPA. Administering tPA in the presence of hemorrhage can be fatal.

itemContext.sbar: S: 68-year-old male presented to the ED at 14:00 with sudden onset right-sided weakness and aphasia. Last known well was this morning around 08:00. B: Patient has a history of hypertension, managed with medication. No known history of stroke or TIA. A: NIHSS score is 18, indicating a moderate to severe stroke. Initial assessment reveals right-sided hemiparesis and expressive aphasia. R: STAT CT head without contrast ordered. Neurology consult requested. Prepare for possible tPA administration if no contraindications are identified on CT scan. Monitor vital signs and neurological status closely.
